E19A2F870DC342289CC084368CE53D95.description: Be willing to consider diverse approaches to resource and land use.

70F6D9D5B0104981956D14C6184560AE.description: Compare and contrast the operations of the Hudson’s Bay and the North West Companies and describe the competition between them.

7648DCB3F0454D4387CE41EEE19C0A5A.description: Describe how the fur trade was dependent on the men and women of the First Nations and Métis Nation.

A9B1055D3235470D93FD7437F2BC1B2D.description: Compare First Peoples’ and European approaches to natural resource use in early Canada. Examples: hunting and fishing, agriculture, trade, landholding and ownership.

98758443DAFF451FA0C6E3CA69980DCB.description:
Describe various ways in which First Peoples
communities interacted with each other.
Examples: trade, cooperation, conflicts.

64CA24D6292C404A9ABF70C89C8FF741.description: Give examples of conflicting priorities between the demands of the fur trade and agricultural settlement. Include: Selkirk and Métis settlements of the Red River.

979D0F509C5848C58BF559F42502344E.description: Describe the organization of the royal government in Nouvelle-France.

F1C27AE9EC8647E6B617F59C8A4F6A94.description: Identify reasons why Europeans expanded their territories to include North America. Examples: international competition, resources, religion, trade.

CC43980CF235411D84FCBF4D0749FA97.description:
Compare types of leadership in diverse First
Peoples communities.
Examples: hereditary right, matriarchy,
democracy.

C6DFC08C542E40308E6E792CA66BC8B5.description: Appreciate the connections Canadians have with various places in the world.

624C06DB3DE14273A200008910C3F79A.description: Identify global factors that influenced immigration to Canada. Examples: political and social issues, European famine, increasing European populations.

E5D1A60C7BD24D88A8D719DA4FEC8D9E.description: Identify global factors that influenced the fur trade in Canada. Examples: European fashion, wars in Europe.

72A4B71F9E35448D83609EEDFBF2E32C.description:
Identify European countries that established
colonial empires and locate on a world map
their areas of colonization.
Include: Portugal, Spain, France, England,
Holland.

9AC838E4BF624B0CA6F80A73AF47287C.description: Demonstrate empathy for the struggles of the peoples of early Canada.

FB7B7E91752D4C2E8803706B73680EB9.description: Appreciate the Aboriginal, French, and British heritage of Canada.

B41B0944D0C945DF80DB1E6AC5E79977.description: Value history as a way of understanding contemporary Canada.

6A0CD7B7835B4E5B9DE81BE4F48BA22B.description: Appreciate the contributions of First Peoples to the development of Canada.

746C0CB3AA7C4CE28022CCA53241064A.description: Value oral tradition as an important source of knowledge about First Peoples.

F72178BC426548818527F9D06E6505EA.description: Describe the roles of individuals in building Canadian Confederation. Include: John A. Macdonald, Georges Étienne Cartier, Charles Tupper, Thomas D’Arcy McGee, George Brown, Samuel Tilley, John H. Gray.

2DDADD7D7D964B619C3BC23316EAE75B.description: Describe the origins of Confederation and give arguments for and against Canadian Confederation. Include: significance of the British North America Act; resistance of Prince Edward Island, Newfoundland, and Nova Scotia to Confederation.

C21333919F6B4C29B8D4035C019D4542.description: Identify people, events, and results of the 1837 to 1838 Rebellions and explain their impact on the development of Canada. Include: Durham Report, Act of Union, establishment of responsible government, French-English relations.

38423EB8A2E143828103CF85BE46F60E.description: Describe the reasons for, main events of, and impact of the Selkirk Settlement of the Red River.

25B6F1C02B6749BBB03488B9864F93E3.description: Identify the causes, major events, and results of the War of 1812.

755C8CE2E412479A8F39D5BC4EDD98FB.description: Give reasons for the migration of the United Empire Loyalists and describe their impact on Canada. Include: American Revolution, hardships, settlement areas, cultural diversity of the Loyalists.

15AC5A415B3045F8A82AD6A96A206745.description: Give examples of the impact of interactions between First Peoples and European traders and settlers. Examples: shared technologies, cultural change, spread of disease.

EE4238F984A34F8184E88EF4D104C561.description: Describe events related to the origins and rise of the Métis Nation.

B9C8085D02A046E79F94862E47D42E72.description: Describe the historical significance of Canadian place names.

C454A1334D3F467DA25B91AEBA46892E.description: Describe contributions of individuals in the settlement of Nouvelle-France. Include: Samuel de Champlain, Jean Talon, Louis de Buade, comte de Frontenac, Marguerite Bourgeoys.

A9BAC7E686BF4383BB1B68E3DF48E84D.description: Relate stories of the people and events of the fur trade. Examples: coureurs de bois, Pierre-Esprit Radisson and Médard Chouart Des Groseilliers, Pierre Gaultier de Varennes, sieur La Vérendrye, Henry Kelsey, Simon Fraser, James McGill.

36823B149B2E439FB3A5CEA9816346EC.description: Describe factors that led to the development and expansion of the fur trade into the west and north of Canada.

292A7BF86AAA4893B0289207AAB6F6F0.description: Describe the influence of the fur trade on the historical development of Canada. Include: Hudson’s Bay and North West Companies; the creation of Rupert’s Land and the western expansion of Canada.

DAE8CFA6404F4E6BBF5AB6A7B6DE4829.description: Describe the major events and impact of the British conquest of Nouvelle-France. Include: Battle of the Plains of Abraham (1759), Treaty of Paris (1763); impact on First Peoples.

2ABD3C238AEB4B30958FCFFC8A37AC89.description: Describe the reasons for and the impact of the Acadian deportation.

724BDDBBA63E46CB91288939A3177203.description: Describe the impact of European wars on First Peoples and French and British colonies in early Canada. Include: First Peoples alliances.

B9C3459B6F6E417F9635E65991ECAADD.description: Give examples of the impact of interactions between First Peoples and European explorers, colonists, and missionaries. Examples: shared technologies, trade, spread of disease.

2E01C4DF61914E56A936029F4415C07D.description: Relate stories of European explorers and traders in their search for new lands or the Northwest Passage. Examples: Leif Eriksson, Giovanni Caboto, Henry Hudson, Jacques Cartier, Martin Frobisher, David Thompson.

39178697D33748D9AD290D1E72BA2E49.description:
Relate First Peoples’ stories of their pre-contact and early
contact with Europeans.

D5BF36D97F2C4EFC85D1ED27EB248A82.description: Appreciate the significance of the land and natural resources in the development of Canada.

83E534F232434981B8BD15E2D24D7E55.description: Locate on a map of western Canada traditional Métis lands and communities.

CA3BD277E305499E932E28B9612BC348.description: Locate on a map of Canada the four provinces of Confederation in 1867.

694BDBF3B6AB4BAB853D8BCA8ED5254D.description: Give examples of ways in which the fur trade operations were influenced by the land. Examples: location of posts, transportation, food, clothing.

45C0CFA01A1D4C879846E2AF9E12E15C.description: Locate on a map of Canada places and regions of historical significance to the fur trade and the Métis Nation.

C2BBA865EB084623B10413FF63BEF1EF.description: Identify factors that influenced the movement and settlement of Europeans in early Canada. Include: natural environment, fur trade, military posts.

1730727A187A4313A1937C76ED9495E2.description: Locate on a map of Canada places of historical significance during early European colonization. Include: L’Anse aux Meadows, L’Acadie, La Nouvelle-France.

4746AB76BB1C4E17B132394D04B3E144.description: Describe practices and beliefs that reflected First Peoples’ connections with the land and the natural environment.

AD8544CE0B484580A4331B51405D3DC7.description: Locate on a map of North America the traditional territories of First Peoples.

46D6DC674F6645FF850C005883217B24.description: Locate on a map of Canada the major physical regions, vegetation zones, and bodies of water.

0E3E36FDA89745D2871B7EB67694BF8A.description:
Describe the impact of the ice age on the
land.

AE5B7D1DD8F2412CAA60CD0987D5F453.description: Appreciate the historical roots of the multicultural nature of Canada.

A714662381FA42B18C834AEC48301F77.description: Value the contributions of First Nations, Inuit, Métis, French, British, and diverse cultural communities to the development of Canada.

7D3BAD2709654CE1AA8EEE61B6649C0D.description: Appreciate Canadian history and geography as important contributors to personal identity.

FE3E4D6F96FC49878B55B1BA79E93B3F.description: Appreciate the contributions of various groups involved in the fur trade to the historical development of Canada.

4EF5A63CA2584414ACC02811D0E0A94F.description: Compare daily life in Canada East and Canada West. Include: language, religion, government, laws.

960E4914C8624850B00D4EC6B060412A.description: Describe how European views of First Peoples changed from 1763 to 1867. Examples: First Peoples regarded as dependents and inferiors rather than allies and equals.

6F92C3DC4FE54833A6CD566DDFD4CBDE.description: Describe ways in which migration to another country or contact with other cultures may affect identities.

6659D8F15FCA4512A37F60383613822D.description: Describe the cultural diversity of pre- Confederation Canada. Examples: English, First Nations, French, German, Inuit, Irish, Métis, Scottish.

8599C4E57966480AA2CD92DB3CC9F4C9.description: Describe daily life and challenges for various groups involved in the fur trade. Examples: coureurs de bois, trappers, trading post employees, voyageurs, factors, women.

9A6E2FFBA2404434BE605E5B3EF793E9.description: Describe the organization and daily life of Nouvelle-France. Examples: seigneurial system, agriculture, religion, les Filles du Roi.

59AF9EA94E2B4FF7931B0E18C1F202F2.description: Describe daily life in early French and British settlements in Atlantic Canada.

240B8421642E41959CA04036763F771F.description: Compare daily life in diverse First Peoples communities. Examples: food, clothing, shelter; roles of men, women, children, Elders.

7BC613BC7D7749C2B009D8D72C646CD8.description: Describe characteristics of diverse First Peoples cultures before contact with Europeans.

B4B152DE24624B45A52CF6D9DD12FF33.description:
Describe First Peoples’ stories of their
origins, as well as current theories of
migration to the North American continent.

5D2E3A0B89084D6AB907B73C5A593ABE.description: Be willing to contribute to their groups and communities.

A8346676469C4C03AF9D6AB180EE3305.description: Respect the rights, opinions, and perspectives of others.

04F09475D0B244549EF70E709164286E.description: Compare what it meant to be a citizen of Canada in 1867 to what it means today.

98F998CF3B164F1E8AAC690E010FB333.description: Identify differences in citizenship rights for various groups in 1867. Include: First Nations, French, British, women.

1677A8A8826649638010C1180A2EF7C9.description:
Give examples of the responsibilities and
rights of citizens of Canada in 1867.

0060B822EFBD4D0E8A91F8AD5EDF1CEB.description: Articulate their beliefs and perspectives on issues.

53539692EA45469AB72E48B3D1DCDDE7.description: Elicit and clarify questions and ideas in discussions.

4035ABDB062944E892C3EF8CC6F86830.description: Present information and ideas orally, visually, concretely, or electronically.

1F12FA2A9F694A4BA9F33EAE07642925.description: Support their ideas and opinions with information or observations.

FFE229074F574B1D9FE26BEA0B717AEC.description: Use language that is respectful of human diversity.

5AC2763D1829464092419C71B642BE2A.description:
Listen to others to understand their
perspectives.

0C7149F27D6C44E1B82D00EF7DDDBFD0.description: Recognize that interpretations of history are subject to change as new information is uncovered or acknowledged.

7CF5EC6F07AF43CCB16CC82E60629A93.description: Interpret information and ideas in a variety of media. Examples: art, music, historical fiction, drama, primary sources.

2F4657078579419BAD028093BC5CE139.description: Compare diverse perspectives in a variety of information sources.

F4C4BD760FD043719AD315646DFD1DCD.description: Compare differing accounts of historical events.

68984F7CC59B4520B1098D6958DC6862.description: Assess the validity of information sources. Examples: purpose, context, authenticity, origin, objectivity, evidence, reliability...

8F2CFF680BBA4D4995FA1221438E1507.description: Observe and analyze material or visual evidence for research. Examples: artifacts, photographs, works of art.

099BA44BB7B047FCBF742BCAC111990D.description: Distinguish fact from opinion and interpretation.

63EF710A0358461987D84CAFE71666BD.description: Evaluate personal assumptions based on new information and ideas.

F1F4EFBBA14C48EAB2BFDE16FD5C60DF.description: Draw conclusions based on research and evidence.

F17038A7ACD142D388A63708F4957AFD.description: Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of solutions to a problem.

278D5061D0804F13B43386118CD402D2.description:
Plan topics and goals for historical inquiry
and research.

CA55FB93255C42D6A6A733A9F3C5EE9A.description: Orient themselves by observing the landscape, using traditional knowledge, or using a compass or other tools and technologies.

1AEBA1B688E44D239BD549F9DF753E90.description: Use traditional knowledge to read the land.

52A4D189ADA347F1AC6933A7C4974F51.description: Use latitude and longitude to locate and describe places on maps and globes.

B8C99F58B4A64A5BBFBCE8A6A7ADED92.description: Interpret maps that include a title, legend, compass rose, grid, and scale.

7690C5FFF6084AD8B3F378392E90D8A9.description: Construct maps that include a title, legend, compass rose, grid, and scale.

4E7461EC95FB4C1F8FA9494E6A84B1DD.description: Create timelines and other visual organizers to sequence and represent historical figures, relationships, or chronological events.

2A9A9B22AD6F424BBCFE137B02FA84BF.description: Select and use appropriate tools and technologies to accomplish tasks.

6D39A68220DF41A9AB3EE5D96487A1DF.description: Distinguish between primary and secondary information sources for research.

2A4FF5DF2E1B4C8FB056F48EF110D8F4.description: Organize and record information in a variety of formats and reference sources appropriately. Examples: maps, charts, outlines, concept maps.

4CAF4B9D03214B7A9C8A16CC7DCFBE4F.description:
Select information from oral, visual, material,
print, or electronic sources.
Examples: maps, atlases, art, songs, artifacts,
narratives, legends, biographies, historical
fiction.

6D8BEE900B9A434EB998E82C6AF49E51.description: Treat places and objects of historical significance with respect. Examples: burial grounds, memorials, artifacts.

D632D5AE141543D9823D77A481410297.description: Recognize bias and discrimination and propose solutions.

9DFFD2AD64B249BB9479824E6A3075E9.description: Negotiate constructively with others to build consensus and solve problems.

03066D7665CF4AF0AE2FE92D717757B4.description: Make decisions that reflect care, concern, and responsibility for the environment.

F2B031D997FA4E2386BB4BCA62CBEDDD.description: Make decisions that reflect fairness and equality in their interactions with others.

D7C63FE695334503B64102AFB3FA9EEA.description: Use a variety of strategies to resolve conflicts peacefully and fairly. Examples: clarification, negotiation, compromise.

36CECD07A1F7402D9E37C78875F92D65.description:
Collaborate with others to establish and carry
out group goals and responsibilities.
